entry.title: Newsletter #110
entry.content:
Hi There!

This week we got a new ping pong table woo hoo! The guys were happy to try their ping pong skills.

Below you can find the usual list of interesting articles we discovered in the past 7 days.

  • [sydphp] http2 and asynchronous apis // speaker deck

  • amazon inspector – automated security assessment service | aws official blog

  • amazon rds update – mariadb is now available | aws official blog

  • amazon web services to add analytics – wsj

  • containing your logical backups: mydumper in docker

  • css polyfills from the future

  • developing with docker at ifttt

  • easiest way to setup ubuntu as a vpn server – ask ubuntu

  • finding a video poker bug made these guys rich—then vegas made them pay

  • getting started with raygun: insights and crash reporting for app developers – tuts code tutorial

  • how to monitor docker-based applications using new relic – tuts code tutorial

  • how to name things: the hardest problem in programming

  • integrating web components with angularjs · pascal precht

  • json-schema faker

  • linux kernel dev sarah sharp quits, citing ‘brutal’ communications style | network world

  • my first 12 years at amazon.com – jeff barr’s blog

  • no comments allowed on reddit’s new news site ‘upvoted’ | wired

  • not awesome: es6 classes

  • optimizing android bytecode with redex | engineering blog | facebook code

  • programming sucks

  • rasmus lerdorf – speeding up the web with php 7

  • react reflux and how to boost your development workflow // speaker deck

  • refactoring to a happier development team – interview with coraline ada ehmke – fog creek blog

  • remote-first vs. remote-friendly

  • rocket internet expects start-ups to break even soon | reuters

  • runnable documentation: code for humans – github engineering

  • sysdig cloud | announcing microservice-level monitoring for ecs

  • tcp over ip anycast – pipe dream or reality? | linkedin engineering

  • testing required, tdd optional | stitch fix technology – multithreaded

  • the debate around “do we even need css anymore?” | css-tricks

  • the debate around “do we even need css anymore?” | css-tricks

  • understanding css: selector specificity — medium
